sources.data_found: APU is one of the nation's few Christian liberal arts universities with an R2 designation from Carnegie; Azusa Pacific University recently announced a $2 million investment to purchase equipment which will enable faculty and students to conduct cutting edge research.

The Department of Computer Science, Engineering, Math, Physics, and Statistics at Azusa Pacific University offers undergraduate degree programs in engineering, computer science, and computer information systems; With a faculty of competent and dedicated teachers, small classes, state-of-the-art computer labs.
The department operates two computer science laboratories on the Azusa campus: the advanced technologies/multimedia laboratory and the computer science main laboratory.
For the academic year 2023-2024, total of 6,487 students have enrolled in Azusa Pacific University with 2,977 undergraduate and 3,510 graduate students.

student_data.notes: Exact CS enrollment numbers not published. Estimated based on: APU has 2,759 undergrads total (fall 2024). The CEMPS department covers 5 disciplines (CS, Engineering, Math, Physics, Statistics). With small class sizes mentioned and assuming roughly equal distribution across CEMPS programs, estimated ~550 CEMPS undergrads total, with CS being approximately 20-25% of CEMPS enrollment = ~120 undergrad CS majors. Graduate estimate based on proportion of total grad enrollment (3,510) and limited CS graduate programs. PhD count marked as -1 (not found) as APU does not appear to offer PhD programs in Computer Science.

gpu_resources.notes: No public information found about GPU clusters or HPC resources at Azusa Pacific University. The university mentions state-of-the-art computer labs and a $2 million investment in research equipment, but no specific GPU infrastructure details are publicly available. All GPU counts marked as -1 (not found). [WARNING: Original source was inaccessible, using fallback.]

analysis_notes: Azusa Pacific University is a small private Christian university with limited public information about specific CS enrollment or GPU computing resources. The university has an R2 Carnegie classification and recently invested $2 million in research equipment, but details about GPU infrastructure are not publicly available.
